See also Monkton (p. 9). The widow invari- ably succeeded in widow-right to the holding of her hus- band for life. The fine (yersuma) on entry appears to have been certain, and not excessive‚ and frequently was remitted, in whole or in part. Without the lord's eon· sent she could not marry again. Under Newton Bewley (p. 59) a widow‚ admitted to two messuages and sixty aeres, is prohibited from marrying again under a fine of four poundS. If she married she remained tenant, and was responsible for the aceustomed services», but she, with her husband, might surrender her tenement. Thus under Ayeliffe (p. 23) we see John F ermour admitted to a cottage which Emma, the wife of Gilbert Randolf, held, and which they (Gilbert and Emma) then surrendered ; and again, under East Rainton (p. 21), we find John Freman admitted to his mother's holding, which she and Robert Thompson, who had married her, surrendered in court to his use. After the widow's death perhaps family considerations rather than oustom regulated the right to admittanee. Under Billingham (p. 104) we find the husband admitted to the holding of his late wife; but under Fulwell the son takes the holding of his mother, and her husband undertakes to repair a grange with a pair of “siles ’² and two “gavil fores'' to the eontentment of the son.
